description:
Happy hour, from 4pm to 6pm, is great. Their menu changes; on their current menu the pulled pork slides, mussels and meatballs are best. Their flat breads are good and light on your stomach, but heavy on your wallet (a bit expensive for what you get.)

Service is better or worse depending on whom you get (as is usually the case). I'e had great service and not so good service in the same visit. I was served a bad piece of meat, in half of their fried chicken sandwich and when I mentioned it to the waitress, all she could do was say, "I'm sorry." You know what should have happened and so did she.

In summary: their a good neighborhood hang out, but inconsistent; no culinary landmark, but not a bad place to drop by and have a drink.
author: Tushar N.

description:
I live two blocks from Palmer's and was really looking forward to it when it opened. Been there about 4 times, twice in the first year, then after a long gap due to the mediocrity of the first two tries, we've tried it again twice recently in the last 6 months (last visit on 10/4): unfortunately I've never had a solid experience here. 

This past visit, had the bacon-wrapped, roasted trout: it was overcooked/dry, and dry ... and did I mention overcooked and dry? Also served with a large pile of forgettable veggies. Definitely not a $26 entree by any measure. Every other experiences here was similar, not even really hitting for average and priced above it. It's strange because I find Leopold's is consistently solid for the German-fare that it serves and its the same ownership group. Bummer.
author: Alex M.

description:
I met a friend here for drinks on a Tuesday evening. They were busy and it had a nice buzz. This has a classic feel, I loved the cozy vibe, colors and the oil lamps on the table. Not a big fan of the animal taxidermy displays though.

Ended up sitting outside by the heaters so we could have a conversation without yelling. Good drinks and appetizers.
author: Sunil R.

description:
okay, this ambiance is AMAZING. I truly feel like I'm in Paris when I'm out on the patio enjoying a cocktail. Ever since I moved here, this has been my "go to" spot. 

Despite the service subpar to put it mildly, the patio and mussels kept me coming back. 

To be honest, after tonight I don't think I'll go back. The service was worse than usual. The server only refilled my water upon my request and I had to ask for more drinks and flag him down each time. He left the table for over an hour without coming back. If they are THAT busy, they need to hire more help. Without getting into a ton of detail, the waiter that works the cocktail area on Friday nights is an entitled prick in my opinion. He's lazy and gives lousy service. Tips are based on performance and I refuse to leave 20% just for the sake of social norm. I waited tables all thorough under grad so I have been there and I get it. 
They recently changed their supplier for the mussels as well and they are fishy tasting and I won't be ordering them again. If I do go back, it will be for a cocktail only.
author: Jillian S.

description: LOVE sitting in the sun outdoors at Palmers! They have overhead heat lamps too! Friendly bartender and service! Great HH selection! I recommend the fries - crispy, tasty and delish! I had the moules which were huge, but I didn't care for the red tomato soup because I prefer the white wine sauce. Bread was warm and had toasty crust too! Paired it all with 2 glasses of Sauvignon Blanc. Just love sitting in the sun outdoors and watching city life go by... :0)
author: Aaa T.

description: Charming French-like Bistro along the Fillmore Street corridor.  Intimate indoor seating and great outdoor patios setting.   Feel like one of the Cafe on the streets of Paris.   Good selection of food and drinks.
author: Lawrence L.

description:
I was surprised at how good the cocktails here! The food isn't anything to go out of your way for, but this was conveniently located across the street from the Clay Theater, so we pre-gamed here before one of their midnight showings. There is definitely a loud, happening vibe here on Friday nights. 

RESERVATIONS: We made reservations just a few days in advance online (8 people, 9pm, Friday). They were very flexible and let us sit late, when only 3 of us were there. Our group filtered in slowly over the next hour, and we had basically a private booth in the back (there was a curtain that drew closed around it!

THE COST: $211.11 before tax/tip for drinks and some dishes for 6 people.  Overall I felt their food was overpriced, but the drinks were fair. 

* Bee's Knees cocktail ($12) - 4.5 stars
Delicious! Refreshing, well-balanced, not overly sweet.

* Penicillin cocktail ($13) - 4 stars
I rarely like scotch cocktails, yet this one was really well made, with a good balance of flavors. 

* Spicy meatballs ($16.75) - 3 stars
Not very impressive. Meatballs were dry, sauce not particularly memorable. 

* Filet of salmon ($26.75) - 3.5 stars
Decent, but expensive for the quality.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
Was shockingly surprised. The decore is quite comfortable, dark, lots of wood. I was there on a Wednesday and there was a surprisingly jumping bar scene going on. At 8:00 I had no issue securing a table for 3 for my friends and I.

Service was excellent. The waitress and maitre'd were both friendly and prompt. Food was shockingly good, I don't know if the chefs were just on tonight but the Devilled Eggs were delicious and original while the flatbread made a filling and tasty appetizer.

The real winner was the duck ragu with gnocci, it was meaty, delicious, rich and filling and I almost kept eating after I was full. We paired it with the mussels which had a very delicious sauce/broth and were fresh and large. With 5 drinks, food, and a decent tip it was about $50-$60 each.

Recommended.
author: Jordan C.

description: I came here on Valentines Day for dinner with my friend who lives in the city. We had a reservation which is probably a must on Valentines Day. My friend came here previously and loved it, so I figured it would be really good. We ordered wine to start and then got the vegetarian version of the gnocchi and then a side of Brussels sprouts with no cheese. Dinner was amazing! I was so impressed and loved every single bite. I would 100% come back next time I am in San Francisco. The waitress was also nice. I'm pretty surprised by the amount of negative reviews I see on this restaurant because I really enjoyed my experience here. A lot of people are saying this place is only for drinks, which I don't agree with because the food was amazing. The vibe of the restaurant is also really cool and unique. I loved the red booths and photographs on the wall.
author: Angelica B.

description:
Stopped by here for a unplanned family meal. Great choice !! I went for the pan seared herb chicken
Entree. One of the nicest meals I've had here. the chicken, veg and mash - cooked to perfection ! Great drink selection and great service - I will be back!
author: Alice M.

description: Wonderful restaurant found via other Yelp reviews. Fun exterior and greeted by the hostess who opened the door and greeted us warmly. Water was delivered to table as we sat. Great cozy atmosphere without being on top of eachother. Food came quickly and as described. Nice experience and would return.
author: Lindsay P.

description: Homemade desserts and great tasting food all cooked to perfection !  Saturday and Sunday brunch is wonderful!
author: Areli C.

description: Great time, great service at Jazz Fest.  Food was fantastic, drinks quick, server was wonderful.  5 star.
author: Brian D.

description: A neighborhood gem. Palmer's has a large contingent of regulars and repeat customers that love: delicious food - hand crafted cocktails - a staff that treats you like family - affordable prices ~ all wrapped up in a classic San Francisco Victorian. The deviled eggs here were the best I've ever had- the mixed beet salad was fresh, delicious and big enough for two. The sage gnocchi was amazing & the steaks here are better and bigger than what most chop houses offer - at a fraction of the cost. A warm & cozy interior presents an inviting setting for a truly memorable dinning experience. Al Fresco dining is also an option if the weather is warm. Palmer's is the complete package.
author: Armando C.

description: One of my good friend came and visited. We had about 10 people in our table. The food was good but the service we had was impeccable. Our server was so accommodating and patient!
author: raimundo t.

description:
We couldn't recommend this place more. The food was great but what took our experience over the top was the service we got for our waiter, Ray. 

We stopped in right before closing hoping to get a bite before heading back to the hospital where my family member was having emergency open heart surgery. As you could imagine we were tired, frustrated, and most of all hungry as we'd been in the ER all day. 

This is where we met Ray. He greeted us warmly and made us feel so welcomed. Asked about our day and was genuinely sympathetic when we told him about what brought us in. From there he made a point to ensure everything we needed was taken care of. He ensured for a brief moment, we could take our mind off what brought us to the city. We didn't order a lot, a burger split between 3 people, but he treated us like we were ordering the whole menu.

It's not often you meet someone who makes such a big impact in such a short moment but that's what Ray did. He was absolutey the highlight of our day and are so thankful to have had such an amazing experience here!
author: Mary D.

description:
We stumbled in here on date night, looking for new places to try. We decided not to stay for dinner because immediately the experience was off to a bad start. We weren't greeted, and finally when he came (15 minutes later, I mean seriously I sat there staring for what felt like forever) it was "what would you like". Simple and nothing more. 

Biggest complaint was the fact that we always received food before our drinks. Such a let down. And one of the drinks was forgotten for 20 minutes, and then randomly slid onto the table watered down. No acknowledgement of the fact that my boyfriend had to wait 20 minutes for his scotch. 

The food was bland, we ordered a kale salad- came with some other lettuce. The sauce was pretty nice actually. But the leaves were too tough, they should have sat for a moment to soften. 

The drinks were strange too. You could barely taste the alcohol in one, and it tasted like there was just pure sweet lime juice and nothing else in my Parisian bouquet. 

The truffle fries were actually pretty good. But the only person around the whole time was the bus staff. The bussers were fast, on top of things, and more than happy to grab us anything we needed (water and sauces and stuff) because the waiter was never around.

Deviled eggs were the worst. I don't know who's idea it was to combine all those random things, and put green oil on it, but it was GROSS. 

Funny enough both tables next to us we're also not pleased- and one gentleman said the bbq sauce with his ribs tasted like pure ketchup. 

The hostess would seat a table and it would take about 10-15 min for people to get greeted. 

We came in for a drink and app and the experience ended up taking an hour and a half. It makes me sad. Just a little more detail and intention and this place could be really great. 

Just maybe encourage your wait staff to say a "welcome in, how are you?" here and there. Sometimes personality can outweigh ALOT OF OTHER ISSUES. 

Also- the faster you are to get the liquor to the table, the more likely people are to spend. Buzzed means you order more. He probably couple have got 2-3 more drinks out of us had that been the case. Booze = money.
author: Sierra B.

description: Food was mediocre. We received almost no attention from the staff even though the place was not packed.
author: Leeor N.

description:
As my friend and I were searched through Yelp for a spot to grab some post-work snacks and drinks, it wasn't a surprise to see Palmer's sitting atop our search on Yelp.  In practically every one of their reviews, the words "happy hour" would come up.  Which suited us just fine since a good happy hour on Fillmore was exactly what we were looking for!  And apparently, if I was ever going to check them out, it should be for happy hour!

Stepping inside of Palmer's, it almost felt like stepping back in time.  Harry's down the street has a similar "old San Francisco" vibe, but it's much stronger here.  The wood paneling, the light fixtures, the metal studded leather furniture, the mounted animal heads perched above the bar...all of it adds to that retro sort of feel.  Fortunately, the menu didn't look have the same dated look, as it offered a solid mix of starters to choose from (much needed, current photos below).

Happy Hour: Daily, 4-6pm
- Food Menu (as of 10/2016): (https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/palmers-san-francisco-2?select=tv6UHw1o3Kbry3XObB698Q)
- Drink Menu (as of 10/2016): (https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/palmers-san-francisco-2?select=wLL2AX3eJ2LhDp5IIP71VA)

-- PIMM'S CUP - Pimm's No. 1, Cucumber, Lime, Mint, Ginger Beer...$8
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/palmers-san-francisco-2?select=wbNh8nKZy-vwBBPRzDNOgQ)
If you've never had a Pimm's Cup before, it's like a cross between a Mojito and a Moscow Mule.  Sadly though, this wasn't as enjoyable as either one.  I don't know if it was the Pimm's, the ginger beer, or the mint, but the drink had a weird tinge to it that took some getting used to, in addition to being a bit sweet.

-- DEVILED EGGS...$2.50 (2 Pieces)
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/palmers-san-francisco-2?select=4MqBa2OUADGOWatmWWA0YQ)
I love deviled eggs, but ironically, I actually liked the rest of the components better.  That's not to say the egg was bad though; it's just that the taste of the yolk portion didn't amaze.  However, I liked the bacon and jalapenos, as well as the pickled onions, as they added salty and acidic elements.

-- CURRIED FRIES...$4
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/palmers-san-francisco-2?select=TqDh3aQj_BXT3uO4r_IgTA)
While it didn't have a strong curry flavor specifically (rather, it just wasn't what I expected), this was great!  Not only were the fries cooked to the perfect crispiness, but they were seasoned really well (not heavy handed, but enough to pack a punch).  I'd definitely recommend this.

Given how little of their food and drinks we tried, I can't say with a ton of confidence how Palmer's ranks overall.  However, after skimming through their dinner menu online, I can see why everyone says happy hour is the best time to come here.  From what I can tell, a lot of the same starters can be had, but at notably lower prices (though still kind of pricey compared to other HH menus I've seen).  In any case, Palmer's may not be a bad bet...for happy hour, at least.
author: Mike L.

description:
Rude bartenders - completely absorbed with cleaning glasses rather than serve customers.   This place is busy due to location, but never ceases to disappoint...as a local neighborhood customer - along with our friends - we've decided to embargo because of the consistently indifferent service.
Recommend going to The Snug across the street - great drinks & team that appreciates customer.
author: Dennis S.

description: After a nice stroll along the Marina, my friends and I decided to eat here for lunch.  Always passed this place heading to work and never tried it till this day.  Parking is very difficult in the area because of all the shops and businesses  around.  The host wasn't as friendly as she should be... sat us down on a table without a wait.  Our waitress was very friendly and engaging.   Hubby and I shared the chicken ceasar salad and the chicken sandwich.  The chicken caesar was not our favorite that day... chicken was very dry and more dressing was definitely needed!  The star of the day was their chicken sandwich...it is probably the best chicken sandwich we've ever tasted!  It had this aioli that made the sandwich so tasty and the chicken itself was very moist!  Besides the not so friendly greeting we got at front, we'll definitely come back just for the sandwich!!
author: Erna M.

description:
Atrocious service:
Sat outside enjoying the sunset.  No hosts/esse in sight. 
10-15 minutes go by. 
We get menus from another customer. 
Wait staff working the table next to us makes no attempt to even say hello. 
We waive hands to no avail. We sit there, relaxed, with empty glasses from the previous dinners and a dirty table.  By now, we are joking that it reminds us Paris years ago when service was usually crap.  My friend is from Stockholm and is shocked how bad it is. 
I go inside and the place is 2/3s empty. No reason to be so bad. 
It's a lovely place. I'd give it another try.  
The table next to us had a much better server, but she messed up their the order. When the bill arrived  for them, items that were not ordered where still on the tab. Every time the guests need help THEY had to get up and search for the servers. It was as they could not be bothered with the sidewalk tables ( maybe drinks only = little tips = who gives a f... ).
Manager REALLY needs to get more involved, their fail.
author: Bruce B.

description: Stopped by for a quite bite and wine on a hot summer day. The cold wine with deviled eggs enjoyed outdoors under the shade was a perfect rest after walking up and down the many shopping spots.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
Whenever we are in Pac Heights we like to stop by this place! The cocktails are awesome and that staff is always cool. If you're more in the mood for drinks, they have a cocktail section in front which is usually pretty busy and fun!  

For cocktails, we especially love the sayulita and the boulevardier. Last time, our server recommended us the doctors order which was also great! 

I've had a bunch of food here, but the burger and the gnocchi are both awesome. The servers have been on point with their recommendations which is always nice too.
author: Rita M.

description: I took my children on a week day for happy hour after school. It was a warm day, so we sat outside and were served promptly. We ordered the pulled pork slider (single portion for HH); fries; the meatball and the bacon Mac and cheese. I have to say that the quality was really good for the price! We all left full and happy. We may go back to have something on the dinner menu next time.
author: L. W.

description: Interesting spot for a drink but did not order any food. Most dishes looked extremely heavy. No wait on a weekday evening.
author: Steven W.

description:
After coming across some crazy wait times for brunch in the area, we stumbled upon Palmer's. Who knew they served brunch in this tavern? There is a dark wood & creepy taxidermy theme going on. On the plus side, there were a lot of large booths. It was early in the afternoon, so we were one of the only people there, but we were just glad to be seated quickly and get fed.

Smoked Salmon Benedict, smoked salmon on hash brown:
This wasn't really a smoked salmon Benedict. A couple strips of smoked salmon sat on top of a potato cake wedge, which almost tasted like focaccia. 
The poached eggs were cooked well with very runny yolk & soft egg whites, and seasoned with some chili powder and chives. They were sitting on top of sauteed spinach and English muffins. It was pretty good!

Brioche French Toast w/ strawberry mascarpone, mixed berries & Canadian maple syrup:
Four slices of buttery brioche toast were accompanied with berries & powdered sugar. The best part was their housemade strawberry mascarpone. It was plenty sweet, so it didn't need maple syrup, in my opinion.

Our friends ordered eggs and toast with a bunch of sides. For a side of bacon, they sure give you a generous amount. It looked like about 10 slices of crispy. A side of sausage includes 2 grilled sausages, which is also quite a decent size for a side. 

Our unexpected brunch turned out to be pretty satisfying. If I were in the area, I'd try Palmer's again for some appetizers or bar plates & drinks.
author: Joy W.

description: I went here on a Friday night and was looking forward to a fun dinner with friends. The service was great, which was not the issue. Unfortunately, I was the only person in our party to have the "Demons on Horseback" (Bacon Wrapped Prawns, Cucumber Salad, Salsa Verde). It should have been called "Demons on Toilet". I got food poisoning and was up all night releasing the "demons". When I finally came around Sunday night, I had enough energy to call the restaurant to give the manager a heads up. I wanted to give them the benefit of the doubt because they did receive a 94 out of 100 health score, and alert the staff about the prawns. The hostess was apologetic and promised that the manager would call when he/she was back. I never received a call back. I am truly disappointed with the managers and more disappointed with the lack of cleanliness from the kitchen. My friends and I will regrettably not be coming back to this establishment. No use wasting your time here if the food is poorly handled and the managers don't care about the well-being of their patrons.
author: Thomas H.

description:
Enjoyed a tasty New Year's Eve beverage at Palmer's. It was a fun spot to pre-party before heading over to our friend's NYE soiree. 

My friend had a Chardonnay, and I ordered the Sayulita (a mouthwatering medley of tequila, green Chartreuse, and some other tasty ingredients). It was a damn good (and strong) drink! Perfect way to kick off the night's festivities.

Palmer's really seems to have found its stride. Looks like the neighborhood has totally embraced this tavern. It's a more mature alternative to Harry's Bar down the street. This is where the adults come to eat and drink. It's definitely more my speed.

I'll be back for sure!
author: Kevin B.

description:
Still my favorite in Fillmore. I love the garlic truffle fries, the burger is one of the bests ever and what about the deviled eggs?? I never have enough!!
Everything tastes better with a Palmer's punch in my hand. I just adore it. It's pure perfection.
author: Angela S.

description: Came here after a meeting with a few coworkers for happy hour. We ordered a few things off the menu to eat family style, and got a few drinks. The atmosphere is pretty cool, is very.... masculine. Dark woods, deep reds, taxidermy animals on the walls. Service was ok, but the food was pretty great. I would totally go back again- for happy hour. Not full price.
author: Morgan P.

description: The plates at Palmers were dirty when we got our food. The service wasn't that great. I did like the atmosphere though. The dirty plates I couldn't get past.
author: Alex B.

description: Low quality food at pretentious prices - all sizzle and no steak. Decor is nice and bar is well serviced but food disappoints. My chicken was dry and my daughter's salad was overdressed to the point of being inedible. Lastly one of the bartenders (young, salt and pepper hair) was downright creepy - bad jokes, sour demeanor, wouldn't leave my daughter alone. Overall nice setting for a drink (IF you can get the right bartender, the bald one was super sweet) but dinner not worth it at all! Blech!
author: Judy D.

description: I really like sitting outside and having cocktails but I wish they would take down the dead animal heads above the bar inside. So creepy.
author: Ess C.

description:
This place has such an awesome vibe to it.   We stopped in for dinner and the place was hopping.  Super cool vibe.  They didn't have a table right away for us but said it would just a short time.   The hostess helped us find a seated at the crowded bar which was cool.   Drinks were outstanding and the service was so quick and top notch especially considering how busy it was.   We had a paper plane and a doctors order.  Both were great.  The hostess informed us our table was ready ahead of the time she told us which was nice (though I could've hung out at the bar all night.  
Dinner was incredible.   We started with the mussels which were served in this amazing tomato and white wine sauce. Then for dinner we had the trout and short rib.  We were thinking of some other options but the server highly recommended these dishes and we're glad we listened. Service was stellar and we again took some recommendation on glasses of wine that were spot on.  Can't wait to come back.
author: Jamie K.

description: Our favorite go-to neighborhood place. Great happy hour, fun service staff, and excellent drinks/food! Can't beat the atmosphere, location, or prices. We love Palmer's.
author: Matthew H.

description: Palmers is the best. Doug is the best. Not only does he know the menu but he created several of the best drinks on the menu. And he recommends custom drinks and that hit the spot. Come to Palmers for the best cocktails and best ambiance.
author: Tessa S.

description: I was in the bay area and was in the Pac heights area visiting from San Diego.  This bar is great very cool! It has a cool old school feel.. Long story short is that i had such a good time drinking anchor IPA that I forgot my cell on a table or something. A week later back down in SD I get a email from the owner asking me if I lost my cell.. I tell him yes, give him my address and 3 days later my cell is at my front door via UPS..  I have lost lots of phones throughout the years and never had one returned after a night of drinking.. For that I thank the owner and his crew of employees.  It says alot about the place.. Thanks again and cant wait to visit in the future!
author: Brett P.

description:
Disclaimer: This review is exclusively for the front bar. Palmer's is a gem. As a happy Pacific Heights resident, I actually find it difficult to find restaurants or bars that are on my wavelength. My friends cheekily remind me that I've been living in the wrong 'hood and should be in NoPa or Hayes Valley. That said, when I finally stopped by Palmer's the other night with some friends I was relieved to know there's a place on Fillmore I'd happily return to. My two friends and I wanted an early evening cocktail to end our weekend. We went in around 7 PM and sat at the bar. We were quickly greeted by the bartender and he provided us with menus. You can order food at the bar as evidenced by the well-dressed gentleman who sat next to me savoring a hearty meal. But, as I mentioned, my party was there for a cocktail party. I ordered a Parisian Bouquet which had gin, elderflower, lime, grapefruit, and basil. It was refreshing and bright. You also have a choice of vodka instead of gin. My friend ordered a delicious chardonnay from their impressive wine list (On a related note: he'd been to Palmer's before and found it charming the first time.) His boyfriend ordered a scotch-based cocktail which he enjoyed. We sat there for a little over an hour and during that time the bartender checked up on us twice to make sure we were good with drinks and whatnot. I appreciated that he maintained his distance but was still attentive -- so few know how to strike that balance nowadays. Another bartender rang us up on the way out and she too was delightful.

The overall restaurant is handsomely appointed: rich colors/fabrics and rustic tavern-like lighting and mood. The ambiance is lively but not painfully loud nor crowded. In other words, it's bustling but you have elbow room. The clientele (at least that night) is a mixed bag of older neighborhood sophisticates, 40-something couples in classic Ralph Lauren, handsome men and lovely women wearing Patagonia, and 30-something ladies in Scotch & Soda-like attire enjoying beverages and juicy gossip. 

Palmer's is now on my list as a go-to spot for a laid-back environment appropriate for friend time.
author: James Z.

description: This review is for the bar only, I didn't have any food (but it looked good). Excellent atmosphere, a real old timey feel and look to the place in the best possible way. The staff was all very friendly and welcoming and the drink I had was terrific. The service was good despite it being very crowded (jazz festival weekend). The drinks are not cheap but they're very high quality and if you're a whiskey fan their list is extensive.
author: Nina L.

description:
Mac n cheese... bomb!
Mussels dish... bomb!
Came across this place at Fillmore Jazz Fest one year and we couldn't remember the name but we found it again and we are fans of this place... yummy food!
author: Mindy C.

description: Nick is the best server! He's so present that there's never an empty glass or a check waiting to be run. As an ex-server myself, I am super impressed by his stellar attention to detail and strong interpersonal skills. If he wanted to work in corporate, he'd probably do amazing there as well. Just sayin.
author: Emyli V.

description: How many burgers have I had in my life? Embarrassed to say in the thousands and probably tens of thousands. This one was one of the best. Get medium rare and really anything on it because it will be good and the burger will be the star. I can also say this is one of the best omelettes I have ever had at brunch. You literally can't lose here and one of SF, no the worlds best. Owner Albert - well done!! He also co-owns Leopolds where you also can't go wrong. Getting back to the burger - perfect meat, perfect soft brioche, perfect condiments and avocado and cheese.
author: Diana S.

description: Took my daughter and her friend to this neighborhood restaurant. Great service perfectly cooked steak and reasonable prices. Love the red leather "clubby" interior
author: John K.

description: Unacceptable. The Radicchio salad had NO avocado, NO blood orange, NO goat cheese, NO pistachios and NO pomegranates. $15 for just Radicchio. I've been a repeat customer for years but I am tired of restaurants reducing their portions and quality to cut costs. Please don't serve this $15 salad if you are going to give customers a plate of Radicchio.
author: Ashley K.

description: Friendly service and pretty decent food.  I especially loved the fries which were crispy!  The ambience is great too.
author: Siv L.

description:
Came here for a drink after dinner at Troya on Fillmore (highly recommend).

I ordered a delicious gin cocktail served up - just how I like it. 

The server kind of seemed in a rush to get us to pay so she could leave but not a big deal. We had a great time and both loved our drinks!

Super busy on a Thursday night around 10 - pleasantly surprised!
author: Ilana B.

description:
Palmer's has one of the best and most generous charcuterie platters I've had. Some charcuterie platters are disappointing with just a few slices of meat but their charcuterie platter has heaps of cured meats. At $20, I think it's a screaming deal. The only other food I've had is the burger which is also really good. 

Palmer's is a great spot for a casual drink, either at one of the few tables out front on a warm afternoon or at the bar inside. They also have a great happy hour with select drinks and nibbles at $5 until 6 pm - not sure which days but definitely seems like it's M-Saturday!
author: Wendy L.

description: Hard to believe I've lived in the neighborhood for several months and just discovered the Palmer's cocktail menu! This is a great spot to come for drinks with friends with a wide variety of creative cocktails available. Plenty of seating after the dinner rush and not too noisy. Will have to come back and give the food a try.
author: Emily F.

description:
Apparently I did this wrong.  You're only supposed to drink here, and only during happy hour when you can get great deals on food.  Mea culpa.  I brunched here, late on a Saturday afternoon, without first reading the yelp instructions:  happy hour happy hour happy hour.   

But let me tell you about brunch.  

The inside was dead as can be and, as a result, looked like a completely inhospitable place to brunch unless one sought alone time with one's newspaper, a bloody mary, a stiff cuppa joe, and food.  There's a market for that and if you're that market, welcome to Palmer's.

There's several sidewalk tables which bring you a little more up-front and center with humanity and signal the onset of a good time.  Of course I brunched there and since I'd done no reconnaissance my expectations were low.  The result?  A tasty fennel sausage omelet, good home-fried potatoes, oft-refilled coffee, and a perfectly chilled bottle of Rosé.  Another dish, an exuberant breakfast flatbread, received a similar stamp of approval from my tablemates. 

Palmer's isn't trying to be the latest thing which probably accounts for the reason it'd never before wound up on my radar.  But often, one just wants brunch, and not from the trendiest spot in town.  Palmer's is nice looking inside and serves up a good brunch and, apparently, a great happy hour.  Tuck that fact away for the next time you just want a solid meal and drinks without needing to book a reservation months in advance.
author: Tracey A.

description: Waited 10 min to get a seat, it took 30 minutes to NOT get the drinks we ordered, and our server gave ME shit. This place is an epic fail
author: Tauasa T.

description: Solid food, friendly service and a good pacific heights spot that is the locals for the most part.  It rarely gets run over by the Marina people, and it has a great neighborhood vibe.
author: F S.

description: Very pleasantly surprised with this first visit. Plush red leather banquettes, brass railings, and a lively bar presided over by Doug, who makes the best Negroni's in the city. Seven of us were there on a Sunday afternoon for drinks and bar bites -- we tried them all, all were delicious, crispy truffeled French fries a winner. Though the place was packed, the service was great, our waitress Jackie took care or our every need. We'll be back for dinner next time.
author: Cathy F.

description:
I've seen three different restaurants birthed and expired here, and thought this corner space on Fillmore Street was cursed. Huzzah for the arrival of the Chosen One, Palmer's, which has weathered the buffeting winds of exorbitant rents and fickle patrons! But, of course, it's owned by the pair who have made Leopold's on Polk (that awesome Austrian gasthaus you look into sometimes, where everyone seems to be having more fun than you have ever had in your whole life and are all holding massive boots of beer) so successful. I imagine those two could single-handedly revive half the failing restaurants in this city. 

Things to love: 
The atmosphere. Very unique and cool, with gleaming wooden surfaces and floors, comfortable, studded, ruby leather chairs, glittering mirrors lined with bottles, high ceilings with elegant light fixtures, and arresting, controversial, and (in my mind) beautiful animal heads jutting from wooden panels above the bar.

The Happy Hour: Unlike some bars, which like to play games by putting their least alcoholic, least delicious selections on their cheap list, Palmer's puts some of its best here--and it has some of the best Happy Hour prices in the whole city. The best drinks: the Old Pal, the Boulvardier, and the Parisian Bouquet (get it with gin)

The Cocktail List: Extensive and fantastic--especially their whiskey drinks. Even when it's not Happy Hour, the prices aren't too bad considering the heights to which so many others appear to have risen in the last year. No idea, though, why the list isn't on their website--there is literally no way to see it unless you walk past the restaurant. Seeing that this is the best thing about the place, I'd recommend posting that menu!

Thing (yes, singular) to less-than-love: the food prices. If it's not Happy Hour, the food here is too expensive. It's not bad, but it's also not great. Were they to decrease the prices a little, or perhaps add some entree options that were less than $20, I might eat here more regularly. As is, this is my Go-To Happy Hour place but not where I take anyone for meals.
author: Ali M.

description:
New creation, the Southern Belle. Must be tasted to be believed. Bourbon, Aperol, Lemon, Bell Pepper, Rosemary.

Not into Bourbon? Eat the Duck Bolognese!
author: Nathan P.

description:
Late night cocktails and drinks - great place to be! 
Very nice decorated and very friendly people working here, the drinks come fast and delicious :)
author: Corinna S.

description: I was very disappoint when visiting this Sunday brunch. The restaurant looked very pleasant. As well as the liter of mimosa. The waiter did not check on us after we received our food. My salmon sandwich came with fries, I received a salad. This is a high end restaurant and maybe we did not fit into their demographic of "wealthy" we would not have spent 20$ on a salmon sandwich anywhere else.
author: Summer N.

description:
This is only for drinks.

Great spot to pop in and grab a creative cocktail on Fillmore. We came in last weekend after a great meal at Pizzaria Delfina. We sat at the long bar that runs parallel to the actual bar. 

Service was pretty fast for a Saturday night with a packed house. 

I love the ambiance. Think old world bar that's just a little more modern than the prohibition era. Though I dislike all the dead animal heads. Not a fan of those. 

The drinks are great. This is one of those bars where they really see it as an art. That being said, the glasses our drinks we're services in were less than inspiring. For the prices, I think we should have gotten something more interesting than boring standard glasses. 

For the boys: the bar was LINED with attractive ladies and no makes. They all looked on the prowl as well.
author: Aggie N.

description:
Review for cocktails only!

Great spot for a first or second date.  It's cozy enough that you want to sit close to your date.  However, it's not so overly romantic that you feel awkward all the other couples around you are playing footsie and you're not.  

Cocktails are delicious.  A little too easy to drink!
author: Chloe M.

description: Excellent food. Good vibes. Awesome server. If you haven't been, you're missing out! Great brunch spot!
author: Mike P.

description: Overpriced and poor service. It seems to attract an inordinate amount of tourists, while locals steer clear.
author: Eric T.

description:
This place was great! Went for happy hour and was pleasantly surprised. Started off ordering some food followed up by a few drinks. 

The food: The burger was amazing cooked just right with a side of curry fries (get the curry fires!!!!). It was medium well and still juicy not dry at all. I was impressed by the portions too.

The drinks: The cocktails were on par served up by mad scientist looking bartenders rocking lab coats. I only had a few but they were masterfully done.

The atmosphere: Very chill old school vibe with comfy booths, a nice sized bar, and deer heads on the high ceilings. Enough room to bring a party and intimate enough to meet people when alone.

Overall I liked it a lot and would recommend it to anybody. Will be coming back soon to explore the rest of the menu. Top notch and five stars!
author: Alex K.

description:
Palmer's is a refreshing addition to Fillmore's many cafes & high-end boutiques. Stepping into Palmer's Tavern transports you into a classic tavern-like setting with red leather booths and animal heads above the bar. 

Although they are known for great cocktails, the food is excellent (and a steal during Happy Hour, 4-6 pm everyday!). Quite a few of their signature dishes are discounted during Happy Hour, including pulled pork sliders, dry rub ribs, and devil eggs. And the curried fries is a must order too!
author: Jessica K.

description: Went back to Palmer's on New Year's Eve to meet up with friends for dinner.  The food and drinks were fantastic. I highly recommend the osso bucco. It was extremely well-flavored and tender. Definitely will return
author: Jeff M.

description: Great happy hour. Classier than your average cocktail and dinner lounge. They have really good sangria and Manhattans. Great bartenders and a friendly host. Fries are the right amount of crispy.
author: Kevin M.

description:
This is a really nice spot - beautiful masculine decor - and a great place for a drink.

I started with a Four Roses single barrel and was quite pleased.

Then we got food - lots of it:
deviled eggs (meh)
kale salad (so-so)
trout (pretty good)
filet mignon with chimichurri (overcooked)

I'd go back for a drink and maybe appetizers, but skip the food.
author: Andrew K.

description: I love this place.  It feels old-timey (1920s?) and classy, which is a rarity in SF. (Is it just me or does everything old feel run down and everything classy feel brand new?)  Anyway, believe the hype on the curried fries (and they go great with ketchup so order extra) and also order the excellent flatiron steak (delicious sauce!) and the classic Vieux Carree (whisky, vermouth, bitters, and some other stuff).  But skip the flourless chocolate cake, which was oddly soggy rather than fudgy which is what you want.
author: Aaron M.

description:
Agreed. Eric was a bit obnoxious. I don't post much but what he did was uncalled for. 

The bartendress was great but I'm not happy about Eric.
author: Chris N.

description: Happy Hour.  Bartender Cory made us the best rose sangria we've ever had.  Delicious! The bargain priced brussels sprout chips were very good, as well.
author: REN S.

description: As a visitor from out of town, I thought this place was way cool and very San Francisco.  We sat at the bar for a late lunch.  I thought the atmosphere was cool (except for the animals heads...).  I got a delicious glass of wine and we split french fries (yum) and mussels (yum again).  Perfect high end bar food in a great location at a neat bar.  I was happy.
author: Carla F.

description:
Palmer's Tavern disappoints on so many levels.

The menu at Palmer's Tavern centers on more substantial dishes and could use the addition of some lighter selections for women or those who are less hungry.  The roasted beet salad was rather small and only average.  Ordered medium-rare, the Wagyu beef entrée ($23) was overcooked and tough.  Served with cheese, lettuce, and pickle on a plump bun, the burger ($13) was OK, but nothing special.  French fries were so salty that they were almost inedible.

While service at the bar was slow, the cocktails ($8.75) that were finally served were well made.  Service in the dining room is disorganized at best and haphazard at worst.  There seems to have been no planning to the waitstaff's workflow, and there is a great deal of wasted effort, resulting in slow, inefficient service.

A surprising disappointment from Albert and Klaus Rainer of the wonderful Leopold's on Polk Street, Palmer's Tavern is trying hard, but failing miserably.
author: CJ G.

description:
First glance, not THAT much different looking from long bar. Unclear why it took something like 2 years to open something here. Warning: the heirloom tomato salad is quite frankly a scam. When I have had a dish named like this elsewhere it is a salad almost totally made of chopped tomatos, think Italian or middle eastern style.

This dish was $11.50 for butter lettuce with 5-6 approx 0.75" cube tomato chunks on top -- almost a joke. Cocktail was fine. Scene was nice. But overall this place is a disappointment, though I am sure I will give it another chance. Food was real amateur hour and they set expectations way too high for a long bar lookalike.
author: alex v.

description:
I visited the City yesterday with my family with the intent on exploring.  When it came down to dinner time we referenced Yelp for a suggestion.  The couple of places were either closed or had too long of a wait time that we did not want to deal with.  We decided to go to the Fillmore and we had a back plan of La Mediterranee - my wife and my first date together - a Classic and a sure thing on reminiscing alone.   As we finally found parking, we walked by Palmer's and I was enamored by the small groups of people eating outside and enjoying a nice libation out in the little bit of sunshine the City had to offer.  We continued to walk towards La Med when I came to a complete stop.  The thought of eating potentially good food in an old world bar atmosphere seemed like a good idea.  I talked my wife and eleven year old son into popping our heads in to explore a little bit more.  We decided to give it a go!

We ordered a deviled egg each which was topped with a small slice of bacon and a pickeled jalapeneo.  It was also served with pickled onions, carrots and cauliflower.  My son opted for the small plates of mac and cheese and creamed spinach - and a large glass of milk - which our server stated, "Hadn't heard that in a while."   My wife opted for the burger on a Brioche bun with curried fries.  I had the pan roasted chicken that was served with Gruyere mashed potatoes and sautéed kale.  And a Ballast Point Sculpin.

The food was delicious - the atmosphere was the type where you could spend hours just sipping on a drink and eating at a slow leisurely pace.  My one regret was that I did not order a cocktail.  I had a feeling that it had a high chance of being made very well.  The barkeeps had a look of experience and looked sharp with their black slacks and white coats.  Absolutely loved the feel and vibe of the restaurant/bar - that it was older and refined.

I would definitely show up for a drink and maybe the burger again or a pork chop.
author: Tony A.

description:
The black caddy helped me grow chest hair.

Not sure what to make of the short white coats though.  Waiters rocking that med student look.
author: Beef S.

description: Don't even get me started about this place ... I waited tables all through college at crowded bars and it's laughable that the owner said this was his busiest day of the year. The back of the restaurant is completely empty but they did not have the decency to acknowledge our table until we went to order at the bar 20 minutes later. We did speak with the owner and he did not even apologize. I would never come back here again... There are a million restaurants in SF with better food and better customer service.
author: Nicole R.

description:
Decent place for quick happy hour and catch up with friends. I like the crowd and the staff is friendly. The bartender was also very attentive given they were busy because the basketball game was on.
Great bar and I alway had a great time every time I came here!
author: Ty N.

description:
I must say that I was pleasantly surprised by our dinner at Palmer's. We were a group of six, looking for a table at 8pm on a Saturday evening. We called up Palmer's and to our surprise they had a booth for us. When we arrived the place was hopping. Super loud, do not go for an intimate dinner for two. Unless you are cool people watching, and not being able to hear yourself think. We had company from London, so with the thought that we wanted to hear each other, the hostess moved us to a back booth with a curtain. Perfect space to dine like a King.

We started off with cocktails and deviled eggs. Cocktails were imaginative and delightful. Loved the Bee's Knees. Deviled eggs were good, and were able to order bacon free if you so desire.

Next we ordered a bunch of plates and shared family style. We ordered the vegetarian gnocchi, burratta with peas, beet salad, flatbread, mussels and burger with curry fries. All except the burratta were much better then expected. I somehow thought it would be mediocre bar food, but was definitely an elevated meal. The big disappointment was the burratta, which was tasteless and crying out for salt, pepper, olive oil and/or aged balsamic. I'm a huge burratta fan, and was bummed that is arrived so bland.

The knockdown from five stars to four was for their dessert options. The menu selection was so boring we didn't even order a dessert to share. They definitely need to kick it up a notch in the desserts.

Staff was friendly and attentive. I would definitely go back if I was with a group of three or more. Again, don't go thinking it is a romantic spot or a great place to catch up with a friend. Super loud, but fun with an old school steak house vibe. Fabulous place to get a cocktail or two.
author: Victoria O.

description:
The location is great and so was the ambiance with dim lighting (but not so dark that you can't read the menu, similar to most steak houses) and room for sitting and standing. Started with the curry fries which I don't regret at all. Crispy and coated in curry seasoning with some ketchup on the side. The gnocchi was excellent, slightly crisped but soft on the inside sitting on top of duck bolognese. I got full about halfway through but it tasted so good I forced myself to eat the rest. My husband ordered the salmon which was also cooked to perfection. If you're in the mood for something light but flavorful this is the dish for you. It came with some crunchy vegetables which was a great touch if you're able to include some in every bite. 

Unfortunately the dessert was nothing like the entrees. We ordered two vanilla bean creme burlees for a table of 6 to share and we ended up sending both back. The entire thing (both of them) were freezing cold and gelatinous, the caramel on top tasted burnt and was crunchy only in the center and not on the sides. If you enjoy creme burlee I advise you not to try it at Palmer's - give something else a try. 

Overall, I enjoyed 80% of my experience there. Service and dessert were not notable.
author: Shireen K.

description:
Atmosphere was hip and light. Large stuffed deer and other forest creatures adorn the walls but don't let this make you think it's a cheesy Tahoe lodge. Stay a while. 

Met a friend for drinks and enjoyed the meatballs (not smokey despite the menu description) and Mac n Cheese (not very flavorful but nice to split). 

Grab a seat near the bar (a lot of stools) and have fun with staff - all of whom were great.
author: Jeff M.

description: Very classy place to take a date or just a casual gathering with friends. Grab a dinner for a business meeting is also great. Service is friendly. There's a full bar menu with wide selection of interesting drinks. It's in the trendy Fillmore.
author: Nessa M.

description:
Stopped here with a friend on Sunday afternoon (just before 5pm). We had appetizers which were pretty good: deviled eggs, pulled pork sliders, and brussels sprouts. The eggs were excellent and we were happy with the other appetizers as well. Our server was nice, although it was a little hard to get her attention sometimes, I think because she was very busy, but still good service overall for the meal. We had four appetizers for $33 --  the quality of the food was great for the price.

It's at an appealing location and the decor overall is nice except for 1) creepy dead animals mounted above the bar, and 2) inlaid Amish-style woodwork around the flat screen tv. This is like one of the bars where the owner decides to add their own special touches instead of using a professional, and the staff are too afraid to complain. At the same time, I really liked the lightning, chairs, and overall decor. The bathrooms were clean and beautiful. It was a nice space.

The only thing preventing this place from being 4 stars is the Sunday afternoon bar service. After the meal, we asked if we could move to the bar to get some cocktails. They wanted us to have the cocktails at our table, which was next to some really loud people shouting that they should short LinkedIn (even though MSFT already bought them). We wanted to get away from these people, and the bar was empty. We also wanted cocktails, so we insisted that we wanted to move to the bar, and the server asked if we could close out our table ticket, which we happily did and then sat down ready for a drink.

It was hard to get the bartender's attention even though there was one bartender and one assistant at the bar, and only about 5 other people sitting with us in the entire bar. Both the barhop and the bartender were only about 3 feet from us, washing dishes, having small talk, adjusting bottles, making drinks, and doing what people do on a fairly quiet Sunday afternoon. 

We sat there for 15 minutes and no one asked us for our order. No one even said "I'll be with you in a moment". We waited. Then we waited some more.  Then I said saying "excuse me, we'd like to order", but was ignored. At that point, I suspected why the waitress wanted to be the one to get our drinks. I waited 5 more minutes and tried a little louder "We'd like to order", and was still ignored. Finally I had to raise my hand (hate doing that) and loudly say "Excuse me, We'd like to order!" at which point the barhop (and not the bartender) asked what we wanted. 

A note to the owner: A good bartender sees everything. Where a normal person would see a throng of people clamoring for drinks, the bartender knows who's standing where and for how long, how many drinks each person had, who is alone or with a friend or on a date. They see all.  You only need to make eye contact, and most of the time not even that. You don't need to say "I'd like to order", as you are at their bar without a drink. You should *never* have to raise your hand or gesticulate to get service at a bar, and waiting for 30 minutes is inexcusable outside of a club of Friday night type environment. This bartender just didn't have a vision of what his customers were up to. He was more in the mode of needing to be prompted for drinks and delivering them -- like someone working at the back of the house rather than at the front. 

Even then, no one offered to give us a drink menu or tried to promote any house specials.  I ordered a Sazerac and was given a very sweet drink which tasted like a splash of vermouth added to an ounce of Jim Bean bourbon and an ounce of simple syrup. They used one of the hip big square ice cubes which would be nice if the drink wasn't supposed to be chilled. A desiccated orange peel was placed across the top of the bucket.  The only thing they got right about this drink was that it's best served in a bucket, although if the bartender knew how to make it, he'd want to serve it in a cocktail glass. 

So our experience was that the meal was good, prices were reasonable, bar was poor, and the dead animals were just creepy. But hey, we had a good time, so three stars. I wish this place well, and with a few tweaks it can earn four stars.
author: Robert S.

description: Stopped in for drink and appetizer, great people watching and staff was friendly. Beautiful day in The City, Fillmore was bustling. 2 beer offerings so if that's what you're looking for check it out before ordering. An extensive drink list.  We decided on appetizers (dinner service doesn't start until later) had onion rings and brussel sprout chips. Both were good.
author: Gwen S.

description: Great atmosphere for happy hours.Awesome drinks and bites! They have excellent cocktails, great wine list and tap beers. Devil eggs are delicious!
author: Tatiana M.

description: Recently made a move into San Francisco, and I've been looking for a good place for dinner and drinks. After a couple visits, Palmer's is my go-to place on Friday nights! My friends and I love sitting at the bar, having the mac and cheese and a happy hour cocktail. My bartenders are always one of the Carloses! They're fun, silly and have a lot of energy! Carlos with the tattoos, he always take the best care of us and makes our drinks just how we like it. I've become familiar with both Carloses behind the bar, and they're both great.
author: Kay J.

description:
My experience her was all in all unpleasant, sorry!
The waitress (petite Asian chick, like me) there showed visible signs of annoyance because I only ordered vegetables (not some hefty, expensive course). She asked me more than an okay number of times (at least six during the entire evening) if I wasn't going to order more food. I had other friends there with me who received the obviously friendlier service because they actually ordered a ginormous burger, sides, and drinks. 
Okay, maybe I should have ordered more since I was seated In a nice, cozy, dim-lit balcony but c'mon I was with friends- and the place was packed, let me be for goodness sake!


Food: first of all, I got the wrong order- so I asked the waitress that she probably had misheard me and she resorted to arguing with me (in a passive-aggressive way with smiles and all) that she absolutely DID NOT mishear. All three of my friends at the table heard what I had ordered and kept supporting me but it took her at least five minutes to give up. Wow. Someone help this chick take her stubbornness elsewhere! 
The food was all extremely oily and salty. I would not order the sautéed/grilled vegetables ever again there. 
...Need I write more into trying to defend my reason for the sour rating? I think this will suffice. 

If you're looking for a nice bar with cozy, dim-lighting, and elegance this place is a gOod choice. BUT- only if you're in a galant, dashing mood that fades the ignorance that may surround you.
author: Grace C.

description:
I came here with a little hesitation because of the Yelp reviews, but we needed a place for a birthday dinner for a party of 6, so we headed our way up Fillmore. Restaurants everywhere seemed crowded and had wait times, and Palmer's doesn't take reservations, but luckily they were able to take us right away when we arrived, so in we went.

And I am so glad we did! From the outside, Palmer's is nondescript and very easy to miss among all the other shops and restaurants. On the inside, it's classy, intimate, and even a little historic, with deer heads and lots of photo frames mounted all over wooden walls. There is also a bar area, which makes it more comfortable. I ordered the entree special, which was a shortrib served on pappardelle and vegetables (25), and the shortrib was super duper tender. Other people got the steak (35), gnocchi (20), trout (24), salmon (25), and lamb (27 and massive), and everyone really liked their food.

To top it off, the waitress overhead us talking about our friend's birthday, and surprised her at the end with ice cream and a candle!

Next time I'll try getting that curtained little table in the back corner. Scandalous.
author: Cynthia W.

description:
Fantastic electric and eclectic atmosphere!! 
Great wine and beverage list and good food items.  I particularly like that I can get an early dinner on those "school" nights and have a raucous time on Thursdays or weekends.  The owners Klaus and Albert are very hands on and keep the quality of the place in check.  And they are great personalities in their own rite!! Staff is very professional without being to stoic.  A definite "must go to" restaurant in San Francisco.  BTW, the Devil eggs are to die for; also the trout and pork chop!!
author: BRENT P.

description:
Our dining experience was excellent! 

5 stars for drinks
5 stars for food
5 stars for service
5 stars for fun ambience

We were a group of 6 on a busy Saturday night and the staff was accommodating, super attentive, and the food and drinks came out fairly quickly. Everything except for the pork chop (too dry) was delicious. Great addition to Fillmore Street!
author: Hanna W.

description:
This place is great! 
I love the food (especially the ribs), the staff is really nice and friendly, and the drinks are great. First Bloody Mary I had after coming back to the States this month and it was superb! Plus I got the one that came with bacon-how can one argue?
author: Benjamin K.

description: I was in the neighborhood yesterday and stopped in. It was happy hour and very crowded. I sat at the bar, the bartender handed me a menu and walked off while I decided what I wanted. Suddenly, something moved on my menu - it was a cockroach. I pointed it out To a waiter who was nearby who killed it and then got me another menu. I only had a drink and I left. I don't think I'll return.
author: David D.

description: One of my favorite cocktail bars in the city. When I saw this place on Fillmore I knew I had to stop by -- it has a classic European style decor: with perfect lighting, high ceilings, and taxidermy on the walls. The old-world historical ambience is rare in SF and I felt like I had been transported to a different city. The cocktails were/ delicious and the service was excellent. I hope to try the food on my next visit.
author: Joe M.

description: When Palmer's is packed, as it often is, the experience really drops off - chaotic, slow, sometimes unfriendly service.  But when it's a bit more quiet, Palmer's is a lovely place for a drink and a snack (wouldn't recommend for a full dinner, as the food isn't very special).  We were there early on a weeknight for Happy Hour and had a great time - drinks were delish and came quickly and the FRIES were insanely good - almost wish I hadn't discovered them, if you know what I mean.  Oh my, they're kind of magical (we got the plain ones).  yummmmm.  Other food items were fine (glad we got a HH deal) but unmemorable.
author: Ellen H.

description: Burger is great!  Bartenders are even better,!  Look forward to the new cocktail menu
author: Michael M.

description:
Absolutely love this place. Just discovered it last night, came back again tonight. If you're looking for a great east coast gastro pub or european brasserie, this is your place. Lively atmosphere, great service, superb food - had the pork chop two nights in a row - and incredible attention and friendliness from the owner, Albert... I've finally found a place in SF that I'll be coming back to again and again and.... :)

PROS: food, small outside seating areas, service, cocktails, ambience

CONS: It is a bit TOO loud, but they're going to address that with some acoustic modifications
author: Marc H.

description:
I really, really like this spot, and I'm a little bit surprised by that!

I've walked by a bunch of times, and always figured the crowd was kinda, well, not my scene. I figured it was bros journeying up the hill from the Marina, and older, richer folks from Pac Heights. And you know, maybe that's true on some nights, but it wasn't the night my lady and I ended up at Palmer's after our own little Fillmore cocktail crawl. 

And what a great place to end up. We sat at the bar, and enjoyed watching the bartender (a big, tattooed gent bedecked in a strong beard and a classic white barkeeper jacket), lovingly create each cocktail. He and the other keep were nice guys--friendly and talkative, but not so talkative as to be annoying. 

I don't remember which cocktails we ordered, but they were served in the old-timey glasses. In general, I'd say Palmer's is paying homage to the 1920s Jazz-era Fillmore Street: a vintage feel with lots of solid wood and incandescent lighting. I like it a lot--it's speakeasy-ish without the pretense.

We also had some food: the burger and the side of brussel sprouts. Both were well-priced, largely portioned, and delicious. Particular shout out for the brussel sprouts, which were cooked in balsamic, and cost only four dollars, for as many veges as you normally be able to buy for $4. Impressive. 

Great place, will return. Holding off on the fifth star for now, as we didn't have dinner proper there, but I expect they'll be able to get it.
author: Allison S.

description: Don't know about the food ... hopefully it's a lot better than the drinks!  Not only did the drink go back because it was bitter, the replacement wasn't any better.  The bartenders need to go to school to learn how to make drinks & in what glass to serve them.  I did not expect to see my drink served in a sherry glass ... it was not sherry!
author: Patricia S.

description: My husband and I really enjoy this place. It becomes one of our regular place to go for a relaxing happy hour.  We loved to sit at the bar and mingle with the bartenders.  We definitely enjoyed their mixed cocktails. My husband current favorite is their Vieux Carree.  They also gave a great happy hour food menu.  We always order their fries, mussels and ribs. Nice drinks, great foods and awesome atmosphere. I highly recommend this place if you don't know where to stop for a drink and bit to eat on Fillmore.
author: Becky K.

description:
Late dinner for 3 people.  Great atmosphere when we walked in.  We were seen to quickly and ordered and received cocktails promptly.  Servers were very helpful, taking time to help me choose what gin I wanted etc.

Service throughout was attentive, friendly and patient.  

Food was very nice, server recommended the gnocchi and I'm very pleased I ordered it.  The texture and flavour was perfect with a little crunchiness on the outside.  The others had a burger and salad which I'm told were both great.  The berry cobbler for dessert was a bit average and my friend ordered gelato which was unusual but perhaps just a different texture than we're used to in Europe.

I would definitely come again for a drink or dinner.
author: Christina C.

description:
Slow service but food and drinks were awesome. Old fashioned and the chicken were a great combo. Spicy meatballs and pork chop also very good.

I'll be back.
author: Julian F.

description: My fiance and I were here on Saturday to celebrate our engagement. We'd arrived early and had ordered a few dishes from the bar when our friends started arriving en masse. The bar area we had occupied began to get a little congested but the bar staff were absolutely superb and kept careful tabs on who was ordering what, and making sure that everyone was looked after. At one point things seemed quite chaotic (in a happy way) but the team behind the bar on Saturday night were simply wonderful. Professional, attentive, friendly. We will both always love this place. Oh, and the meatballs - epic.
author: Dustin S.

description:
Ambience- Corner location with awnings and warm lighting make for an inviting vibe.
Food- ok to very good among the five items we ordered.
Drinks- lots of choices; good atmosphere 
Service- What is there to say?? Waiter slipped a second bottle of wine onto our bill, not just any bottle, but one that increased the bill by 50%. I caught it as he was walking away and he instantly grinned saying "Oh you probably want that removed from your bill" as though it was a joke. Guess my sense of humor is impaired...

The place is attractive from the street and interesting inside... A mistake? A cabal of thieves? The one bad apple? In this neighborhood I won't need to sort that out any time soon.
author: Bailey D.

description: Nice visit on a Friday night couple of drinks and some apps. Flatbread was a little undercooked. Sliders and shrimp however were nice. Worth another trip back. Good atmosphere.
author: Randy R.

description:
I had been going to Palmers since they opened. I have a small service animal due to a medical condition and he goes everywhere with me. We have been in Palmers more times than I can count. Yesterday I dropped in mid-afternoon and asked to sit in my usual spot. The hostess was unfamiliar to me and immediately started stressing about my dog being with me per usual, 100% of the time I go there. She said I couldn't be seated unless he was placed on the floor. I explained that wouldn't work for us since he needs to be close in order to manage my condition. I offered his paperwork and tags. She was not listening to me. Wait am I a customer, am I a human or something else to her? She stopped making eye contact and became abrupt and rude. It was if I was nothing.

Some of you might be thinking oh a service dog, a bogus claim to get into a restaurant like so many in San Francisco. That's not the case. He is silent, trained, always swaddled and covered on my lap so as not to get on any furniture and as he has been trained.  He was professionally trained for 8 weeks as a puppy. He never ever gets near food, begs, etc. In fact, nobody ever notices him unless I am entering or leaving.

She didn't care she didn't want to see my paperwork which by the way is illegal to ask for. She's breaking the law in fact by even asking. I am sure if I were blind or deaf or with a large dog she would have rolled out the red carpet for me. I am not blind I have a chronic illness covered under the ADA that requires him to be with me.

One of the worst parts of this experience was that I am a regular customer with no familiar faces to greet me and an uncaring person treating me like I was nothing. It's NOT OK and anyone reading this that cares about people like me I don't recommend spending money and time at Palmers ever!
author: emily b.

description: Palmer's is my favorite date spot! Great staff, GREAT food, a bit on the pricey-er end, but worth your money. Go for happy hour! You can get their best dishes in an app size and the drinks are amazing. Get the Pimm's cup!
author: Clay P.

description:
Palmer's confuses me. 

For a while my husband and I were going to Palmer's for dinner pretty often. Most of the food we've had there was delicious. The lamb was incredibly tender and flavorful. The pork chop was incredibly moist. The gnocchi with duck bolognese was to die for. 

And then I had the steak. It was not only overcooked (I got medium instead of medium rare) but it was also completely unseasoned. Not a dash of salt or pepper. It must have been a fluke, right?

A few months later I decided to try the steak again. This time it came medium-well so I didn't even try it, I cut into it and sent it back. My new steak came undercooked (which I prefer but still, not what I asked for) and again it was completely unseasoned. The mushroom sauce it came with was also completely unseasoned. My husband's burger, on the other hand, was perfectly cooked and seasoned. 

I don't know how they can get their steaks so wrong and everything else so right.
author: Sofia F.

description: Good cocktails delicious pulled pork soldiers and dry rub pork but portion were really small.
author: Aj K.

description: Food and service were lovely. But on Friday night it was so, so noisy that my dinner companion and I were literally shouting at eat other (ironically contributing to the noise level) and had trouble holding a conversation. I would definitely come back on a less busy evening.
author: Barbara N.

description:
Nice neighborhood restaurant. We ate at the bar. I had a burger which was cooked just right. Added blue cheese and bacon to my burger which they accommodated. 

They have an assortment of New Zealand wines which is very unusual in San Francisco. Overall, the service was good and the location is great and very vintage atmosphere. It just lended to the areas charm. I will be eating here again.
author: Jessica M.

description:
My husband and I came upon Palmer's by chance yesterday afternoon when we mistakenly went north instead of south when looking for a particular shop on Fillmore. What a happy accident! The beautiful Palmer's sign drew us in. We were seated immediately in the gorgeous, high-ceilinged dining room. It was brunch time. The menu was fairly small, but everything on it was interesting. I had the grilled flat-bread with bresaola, gruyere, fried eggs (cooked perfectly) arugula and - wait for it - onion confit. It was a rather massive portion for only 12 bucks - hubby had to help me finish it, despite having polished of the vegetarian frittata on his own plate. We were not going to waste a bite of this dish.

I also had a glass of excellent grenache rose - just delicious. And I would be remiss if I did not mention the excellent service. The host, the server and the owner were all smiling, attentive and genuinely kind. The whole experience was a total mood-elevator. We'll be back!
author: Amy B.

description: Palmer's drinks are great and foodwise is very good.  Brunch is  also very good.  I am surprised it's a bit empty for brunch (they open at 11 AM).  Brunch burger is massive and juicy (bacon, fried egg, avocado) and the omelette is tasty.  If you want to meet friends for brunch without the wait and have nice conversation, Palmer's would be fantastic choice if you are in the area (or couldn't wait for Elite Cafe brunch).  Service is fine and no issues.  I feel Palmer's is the grown up (more mature) version of the Brixton (youngish crowd on Union) but with better food.
author: Mr. C.

description: I've been here a few times, and thought Palmer's was ok. But I came in this weekend and was delighted. Lovely service, cocktails and lunch. Salmon on the salmon sandwich was perfectly prepared. And chocolate mousse cake was delicious. I look forward to returning.
author: Kirsten Z.

description: We had reservations here and our table was ready right on time but the entire meal I felt rushed by the waiter. He tried taking our menus and our plates before we are finished with either. The food was fresh but just okay. We had bacon wrapped scallops and a buretta cheese plate. At the end the waiter came up and said we need your table for someone else so I basically felt kicked out of our reservation. If I ever go back there I will definitely sit at the bar because the bartenders were super friendly and very attentive, but I wouldn't recommend this place a good date spot if you plan on making a reservation.
author: Kelly M.

description: I would give this a solid 3.5 stars, but alas, Yelp only allows stars without decimal points, so since I feel like it was OK and I'm not a total fan, I'll go with the 3-star rating. Went here my first night of a weekend visit to San Francisco with Sam C. It was within walking distance of her place, which was great, especially since the walk to dinner was more/less downhill (meaning the walk back did mean we were going uphill!). It had a very neighborhood-like feel and was definitely packed when we got there. They had a table for the two of us in the back and when we got back there, it was definitely HOT. We were seated and our waitress came by and got our drink orders (red wine, please!) and then we agreed to do some sampling and splitting of things from the menu. We shared an iceberg wedge salad, which was exactly what you would have expected for this type of salad. Then we split some orders of pulled pork sliders (yum!), a Palmer's burger, French fries and Burratta (which I personally thought was a disappointment). All in all, it was great to visit with a fantastic friend in a convenient spot with good variety and plates that were shareable. I just thought for the price of the food and wine that the quality of our meal would have been a little bit better.
author: Christa S.

description:
Came by on a weeknight for a couple apps and drinks:

Pretty hoppin' place!  Lively, nice ambiance.  

Flatbread is just ok. I recommend the meatballs.

Cocktails were good. My husband and I sat at the bar, and the bartenders were friendly and could make a solid drink!
author: Riz W.

description: Really fun place for drinks and food. The ambiance is a combination of Chicago and the northeast. I come by once a week and it's always a good time. Try the shrimp app!
author: Scott K.

description:
4 Stars: service, ambiance, drinks
Negative 2 stars for the food. Ordered ribeye for two- Within what was definitely the non-ribeye'est cut of meat was every thing except flavor- from bloody to very well done all within one steak. And the sides tasted like nothing (gratin potato) or salt (spinach). 

Step it up Palmers. I eat a lot and know what I'm saying.
author: David L.

description:
The best part about Palmers is the service, particularly the dinning room. I was provided with 5 star service which was thoughtful and prompt, better than any I've had in SF. The food: Not very impressed. The wedge was lackluster and missing more of everything. The burger would have been good if it weren't so charred. The mussels were GREAT and so were the fries!!!!!
The decor and ambiance are also great! Very charming 20's vibe and huge bar, If you are meeting up for drinks & appetizers this is the place to do it. On our way out we got a thank you from 4 people including a bar tender, That was impressive!
author: L V.

description:
Since it's very close to my house, I come here pretty often. The cocktails are delicious, creative and strong. The food is good, somehow always better than I expect it will be even though the menu is sort of typical American cuisine. 
I always get the deviled eggs...always really good. 
Perhaps it is because I usually end up drinking several of the above mentioned strong and delicious cocktails before the food. 
The service has always been super friendly. When it gets crowded you might get a bit less attention but I've never had an issue here.
author: Nilu r.

description: Great place to get a bite to eat and some beers/cocktails! So much fun to sit by the window or at the bar. They have a nice selection of beer, wine, and cocktails. The French fries with the curry spice was so delicious. It went perfectly with a cold draft beer. :)
author: Kyoko T.

description: Stopped in for a drink, and was delighted with the service we received. Carlos was our bartender, drinks were fabulous, service and personality were even better. Highly recommend this place for the drinks as I did not eat here...well their bacon was really good in the Bloody Mary!!!
author: Amy B.

description:
I hate to do this.  I really do.  But this experience is like poison that I have to get out of me by telling someone.

My experience is solely with the bartenders/drinks.  I can't comment on food.  My story begins with a perfectly reasonable cocktail, Diablo something, ordered from a friendly bartender at a reasonable $8.50.  I went back and wanted something a little stiffer.  This is where my tale begins.  

I asked for a double Makers on the the rocks.  The bartender types in a Makers into the POS.  Its $9.  I can SEE this with the EYES I have on my head.  He then clearly is puzzled as to how to put a double Makers into the system.  He heads off to my right to speak with what must have been the manager.  He comes back with my drink and my receipt.  "$27 dollars."  Im rather surprised that a double makers cost $18 more than a single.  "27 dollars?", I say.  "So you are telling me a single cost $14.50."  Looking me right in the eye - "Yes."  

I don't argue with restaurants, I don't send food back, and I never complain to anyone.    I wasn't about to start here.  I sign the check, even give a tip.  The point here is instead of checking on something that seemed wrong, ie a $27 dollar drink, he looks me in the face and charges me that amount.  Screw you dude.  Check on that.  

I wish my story ends there.  However after drinking my cocktail I want just one more.  I head back to the bar and avoid eye contact with previous bartender.  I don't want to complain, I don't want him to comp anything, I just want to avoid the situation and get charged properly.  I also don't want to order a single Makers and seem like I am "testing" the price on him.  Just trying not to be a jerk here.  

To avoid any confusion and keep the price down, I order a "whiskey on the rocks".  When asked "What kind of whiskey would you like," I respond "whatever is fine".  Mind you today is not my first rodeo - I have ordered drinks before.  Generally, when a patron does not specify the type of drink they would like, they want the cheapest you have because they are indifferent.  However, the bartender elected to serve me a $10 whiskey.
